intro: Quercus crispulimongolica, commonly known as the Mongolian crinkled oak, is a deciduous tree native to the grasslands and steppe regions of Mongolia and northern China. It is characterized by its distinctive, crinkled leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, giving it a unique appearance. The tree produces small, acorn-like fruits that are an important food source for various wildlife species. It typically grows to a height of 5–10 meters and has a broad, rounded crown. Quercus crispulimongolica is adapted to harsh, arid environments and plays a vital role in stabilizing soil and supporting local biodiversity.
